comments.text: "The thing I'm doing is the best way" - every fitness channel
comments.author: @aguy446

comments.text:
Excellent analysis! When I trained back in the late 70s and 80s, everyone in the gym was doing similar workouts because we all read the same magazines. We did what worked for the champions at that time. Here are the reasons why old-school bodybuilders looked better, including some that were mentioned:
1. Sunlight increased muscle tone. See the video "THE SUN CURE - Restoring The Lost Art of Light As Medicine"
2. Ribcage expansion work built large, Herculean thoraxes.
3. Serious, high-rep and set ab workouts, multiple times per week, made the waist muscles small, and tight. This made the shoulders look wider. The ab routine in Arnold's book "Education of a Bodybuilder" was 5 x 50 reps each for Incline Situps, Lying Leg Raises, and Broom-stick Twists.
4. Big calves! Standing, seated, and donkey calf raises, 5 X 15 reps, multiple times per week. 
5. Lats sweeping down all the way down to the waist from full-range (leaning WAY forward) cable rows and T-bar rows. Also barbell rows with the back parallel to the floor, standing on a block, letting the bar all the way down to the toes!
6. Stretching between sets making the muscles long and graceful looking, especially the lats and chest.
7. Wide grip chins behind-the-neck were very common. They stretch the ligaments of the shoulder blades, making for a wider front and rear lat spread.
8. Shorter rest periods with reps in the 8-12 range. When Arnold arrived from Europe at Gold's, he called it training "California Style" with only 1-min rest for smaller muscle groups like shoulder, arms, calves, and forearms; 1.5 min for chest, back and legs.
comments.author: @jimgurtner

comments.text:
It's because they didn't over complicate it. Old school guys here in our gyms are just every day men. Taxi drivers, construction worker, security guards, laborers yet they're the most jacked especially for their old age. They give the most ridiculous advise and programs.

But why are they still jacked and in shape?

Consistency. 

Most of these men only had access to one or two copies of  a bodybuilding magazine, most of them probably saw one or few training routines and just stick with it their entire lives, meanwhile most of us new lifters overcomplicate and get baited by the latest study the latest program our attention spans are too short.

And why were they so jacked despite having little to no equipment because they make the most out of it.

I've seen guys in poor gyms have better bodies that dudes who can afford commercial gyms. They train in scarcity, they make the best out of it. Meanwhile dudes in commercial gyms have wifis and are glues to their phones or too bored in their gyms they just try each equipment and hop from one machine to another.

I used to be this guy. Now I've seen the most progress by simplifying anything. Went full body 3x a week, 2-3 working sets 5-6 reps (if I can do 8 then I add weight until I can 5-6 reps max again)
comments.author: @Samson2323

comments.text: The editors of muscle mags only used the best artists , a time when meritocracy, talent and American culture mattered. The photographers didnt  just appreciate the beauty of the male aesthetic, they saw it as a symbol of the greatness of mankind. Specificaly the great men of the West who built the modern world. Their photographs  inspired young men to not develop their bodies for narcissistic pleasure but  to pursue greatness in everything they do. To build a world of prosperity and freedom for all. They inspired boys to see manhood as a time to prepare for, to get big and strong in order to serve  something greater than themselves,  to defend the weak, to build community, to defend country, to worship God. It was a time of patriarchy.   Today anyone with a phone can publishing photographs, usually focusing on crass, extreme fetish,  or overt narcissistic self worship and false idolotry. Today's images reflect the feminist destruction of patriarchy and their attack on men through systematic weakening and blurring the lines of gender roles. The feminization of everything has caused division and confusion rather than inclusion and unity. Matriarchy, the radical far left kind, seeks to destroy everything created by patriarchy, including  art and the portrayals of men in art.
comments.author: @GayBroBud

comments.text:
My reading of the science is this, and it's actually really simple: do enough volume, in an effective range of motion, with decent form, close enough to failure on every set.

I've been at this ten years, so I've had plenty of time to figure out what the "enough" is for me in each of those. Knowing what works for you and what you can recover from, is way more applicable to you than knowing the details of this or that niche exercise.

The basics get you 95%, the science makes that clear. Reasonable people can argue on optimising the last 5%, but until you get the 95% dialed in, don't worry about those last details.
comments.author: @Mikey__R

comments.text:
the thing is weightlifting from the 18th century to 1970's was CrossFit/Hyrox, kids in schools/gymnasiums were doing gymnastics jumping over wooden horses climbing ropes body weight exercises,Olympic lifting,powerlifting, strongman, kettlebell training flexibility cardio,boxing, wrestling, they did it all , they didn't just focus on bodybuilding, 

look at Arnold as a prime example  track and field/Olympic lifting/powerlifting/ bodybuilding, 

bodybuilding changed in the 80s all came down to being the biggest and leanest person on  stage and using as much drugs as possible, bodybuilding is much more easier nowadays so many machines people use and do not build real life strength like old lifers did

comments.text:
This diet is much less about being and staying lean than it is about just feeling better, sleeping better, having a better immune system and not get sick as much. 

I've always been lean, but about a year ago switched to 80% whole foods, no added sugar, minimum seed oils and processed foods. My inflammation and back aches are gone (had 2 back surgeries), feel tons better, sleep rhythm is great, excess energy, put on muscle much easier, no mood swings, and my skin looks better. Went back to visit old friends this week and have already gotten several comments about looking younger and healthier. We all need to go back to basic ancestral foods without labels. Organic meat, eggs, fruit and vegetables, thats it. Get what you can from local farms and markets. Videos like this is the real deal guys, you can do it!
comments.author: @klatre

comments.text: Great video! I am 77 and have weight trained for 47 years. Not many people your age have the common sense and discipline that you have. I dont eat much red meat. Usually a grass fed 6 oz beef pattie once a week with a baked potato and a vegetable, usually broccoli. I eat mostly chicken and fish with veggies and or salad. Also 8 or 9 eggs a week and of course hydration, 2 to 3 litres a day. I am 5' 9"  170 pounds with 12 % body fat. I workout 3 days a week and play hockey one a week. It is so simple but not easy. I do take whey isolate once a day and creatine.
comments.author: @johnferguson5739

comments.text:

Also and Im not being sarcy, you must spend hours prepping, and cooking that food each day. Not everyone has the time, for work, "life" training, and all that cooking. Still a great video.

Listen ive gone down from 230 to 190 with maybe going to the gym 3 times a month.
Cut your calorie intake to 10 cal per target weight
You wanna be 190 consume 1900 or less calories.

Cut majority of sugar, and fast 20:4
Its that simple. I have zero stretch marks, zero extra skin.

You have a 4 hour window to eat whatever minus processed sugar.

You dont have to cut carbs, you donâ€™t have to go on some keto bullshit. 

Calories in and calories out is all it takes to lose weight period

comments.text:
Hey @averagetojacked, I found your channel recently and really like the approach. For context, I'm a 39 year old guy living in Switzerland who has been lifting for about 10 years. I'm 88kg (180cm in height) and fairly muscular - at least enough that people seem to remark on it when meeting me, etc.

The problem is, I have little kids now. My workout used to be 2 hours per day, 5 days per week. That's now impossible. I've slowly reduced the number of days per week, and number of sets per exercise slowly over the last few years (all before discovering your channel). I'm now at 3 sets per body exercise. So, 3 sets of incline bench, 3 sets of dips, etc etc. I ALWAYS go to failure, to the point where my form gives out and on some exercises I feel sick. I trust I'm really pushing it for each set.

However, my workouts are still a solid 1.5 hours, abeit now only 4 days per week. I arrive at the gym at 04:45 every morning so that I can finish before my kids wake up. But it's very very exhausting after several years of this, plus a full time job of course.

I started watching your content recently, and I would love to change to your method â€” if only so that I could reduce wayyyy down on my workout times. However, if I'm really honest, I'm just scared that if I go down to ONE SET per exercise (ðŸ˜±) I'm going to lose all the gains I've built up over the past 10 years.

Even if I just go down to 2 sets per exercise would save me so much time. I can't imagine doing 1 set per exercise.

Can you say anything to reassure me that it will work and I won't lose everything?
comments.author: @Monkey2ewok

comments.text: I think this advice can be harmful to those of us who barely got to 30% of our genetic potential and got stuck there. You can' be doing this until you are approaching elite. I very, very stubbornly decided to stick to Mike Mentzer's final (thinï¼‰book while at barely 30% of my genetic potential - for year and year and never progressed. That was working out legs every 4 to 5 days once. It does not work, you do not progress. I started seeing progress again when I started doing his split routine DAILY for 4-5 days in row and inserting 2 or 3 days off after. Those of us who barely have any muscle cannot get stronger with such infrequent single set 20 minute workouts IMO. I have no idea why Mike Mentzer didn't know this, I think because he NEVER would have trained someone who was a beginner, everyone he was dealing with had so much muscle mass they really did need the recovery days. I'm just saying this because I was off-track for about 5 years.
comments.author: @parasitius

comments.text: wait, what do we mean by "now?" science has been agreeing for years with minimalism. how many years has it been since jeff himself released his essentials program? and in recent years minimalistic training even has its own name now: the "minimum effective dose." i feel like people just see what they want to see and hear what they want to hear, which is new news that is also good news. but nothing is really new, and everything is quite good. i also feel like people are still somehow missing the point of the minimum effective dose, which is that a maximum effective dose must also exist. so, volume is still king. more is LITERALLY more. but less is more than enough, and more people are realising that enough is enough. that's what's really going on here imo
comments.author: @YeahTheDuckweed

comments.text:
I mean, Jeff is barely science-based to begin with but he just does something different for 3 months at a time to sell a new slop level program. You can just look back at his history/pipeline of "i tried x for x months - you can buy my program down below in the description". It's every time he releases a program. I'm sure hes a nice enough guy, but his content and programs are just slop thrown together using "science based" as a sales pitch. Jeff has a track record of interpreting data incorrectly and just running off of the most recent study shows "x result in x trainees". It's science for toddlers and beginners who don't understand what hes doing, because those people are easy to sell cheap shitty programs to.

Bro lifters worked this shit out decades ago
comments.author: @Tom-wk6pv

comments.text: Coming back from tearing both wrist/forearm tendons... 20 months later and I am VERY concerned about re aggravating and I am NOT doing anything HARD. Id rather slowly get to where I was before rather than lose all my gains like I did before! I tried to do more reps cause I was lifting light but going to failure re aggravated the right wrist/forearm! One week off hopefully I can still train! Starting again in two days!
comments.author: @DJDonkeytron

comments.text:
Here's my problem, the men with the best physiques, use like zero science and do all the stuff were told not to do, high volume high intensity train multiple times a week.... I have stopped trying to explain it with science, Ive stopped trying to rationalize
 it, if you want to get big train like you have a gun to your head. Ronnie one of the greatest BB of all time trained like a powerlifter, mike Mentzer would have beaten Arnold and took the title if he didn't let one loss get to him, train like a monster. Forget science forget what's in, JUST SHUT UP AND LIFT.
comments.author: @PrimarisDeiPrununs

comments.text:
@averagetojacked 100% agree on low volume. How do you maintain the intensity on a calorie deficit, though? Interested in your strategies.

Side note: with Wegovy / Ozempic becoming mainstream, thereâ€™s more people working out in deficits than ever before, yet theyâ€™re not getting enough protein, eating mostly hyperpalatable foods, etc. The answer is still â€œdo it rightâ€, but I am trying to figure out the best advice/strategies to keep our nation from all being skinny fat or giving up
comments.author: @prestondunlap8228

comments.text: Dorian yates has been telling you all since the 90s ðŸ˜‚
comments.author: @lordmac-b6v

comments.text: Started off about 2 years ago and was going 6 days a week. While it was fun and I was noticing results fast, the fatigue was just catching up to me. Now Iâ€™m on a 3 day PPL split and itâ€™s such a breath of fresh air. I think weâ€™re heading into a wave of fitness where less is truly more as long as you put in the effort each session and recover properly
comments.author: @zBatos

comments.text:
jeff is in it for the money
in 6 months he will release another program
remember lengthen partials? if they were so effective, why didnt he include them in this program as well? 
because all he does is pick a training style & make shit ton of money from the books
long live reddit
comments.author: @Luther7021

comments.text: Can you talk about how hard the sets should be ? Reps on reserve ? Sets to failure?  If I'm doing 3 sets of 8-10 reps how close to failure should each set be on different exercises?
comments.author: @jensammi

comments.text:
Intensity is everything. When I grind through the last two hard reps, I progress quickly. When I stop short of that I can stall out for weeks.

Your body needs a reason to grow and stopping the set within your comfort zone doesn't create a reason.

2 intense sets > 4 relaxed sets.
2 intense days per week > 4 easy days.
comments.author: @natanelarnson

comments.text: I don't know if I would say he "proved" anything. He has a new program, is a very experienced lifter, and needs a more balanced life. I don't think that level of intensity is possible for most people with less than several years of consistent working out.
comments.author: @Sa3vis

comments.text: What if you trained every day but focused on just one muscle group per session? For instance, hitting the chest only once a week or even once every 9â€“10 days. Would that approach fall under the idea of less is more?
comments.author: @martyhum6263

comments.text:
Been training exaclty like that for 21 years, and I still don't look like a bodybuilder. 

Too fat. But whenever I diet (correctly), I start losing strength, energy, size and the will to live.
comments.author: @ifstatementifstatement2704

comments.text: Why is everyone so excited to spend less time in the gym? The gym is the only place I feel alive. What do people do on the non gym days thatâ€™s so much better than working out?
comments.author: @jt23jt55jt

comments.text: Let's dont get this wrong tho... He is on a cut and he knows that he won't be gaining any muscle while cutting, this is why he is doing low volume. He still thinks you can up the volume as much as you can while bulking because it is easier to recover on a surplus.
comments.author: @alperbasiyor

comments.text:
I started doing these type of workout for 3 month now. 
And what took me 2 years to gain was achieved seriously as fast. While also being stronger and having good rest.
comments.author: @msc807

comments.text: LOL, Jeff Nippard...wait till you find out who Mike Mentzer is and his HIT program ðŸ˜†ðŸ¤¯. Nothing is new under the Sun.
comments.author: @timkourbo3196

comments.text: Working out 3 times a week is legit the most optimal. Itâ€™s the most sustainable long term and ensures your body has enough recovery time.
comments.author: @Geol3dg3

comments.text: Going to give this a try. I feel burnt out and don't enjoy training much anymore.
comments.author: @user-nt4sl5hp5m

comments.text: mind is based on pleasure. cells of the body based on stress and evolution. therefore techniques you enjoy but at same time you can push the muscles and cells above and beyond their capacity marries the two.
comments.author: @Galacticmaster

comments.text: You're supposed to alternate between high volume and low volume. It's not a one method thing. I swear people have no idea about what periodization is.
comments.author: @justwannabehappy6735

comments.text: jeff has been bsing for 10 years. everything boils down to mike mentzer
comments.author: @neo22501

comments.text: Can you do this for a 3 times a week full body? Like 1-2 sets per exercise?
comments.author: @Hugo97HD

comments.text: When you say low volume, what does that look like? How many sets per muscle group per week?
comments.author: @Massimo_56

comments.text: But wasn't this said by Mentzer? High intensity is sufficient.
comments.author: @overlord165

comments.text:
Respect to you my man... but dont qoute Nippard. 
https://youtu.be/WWgOPZ_TFSk?si=y3LgvDyvtdtrcC57
comments.author: @TheVratilo

comments.text: PLEASE DON'T CHANGE A THING! I heard you talk about others saying your videos are repetitive. I LOVE YOUR VIDEOS! Repetitive or not, they're simple and to the point. Thanks to your magical phrase, compliment not consume, I changed my workouts to what you do. I'm 47, worked out over 30 years. 2 hours in the gym. Got results and it was fun but now seeing your routine, I changed mine to yours. I'm happier now, I have more time for other things, I feel great. Please don't change anything. If it ain't broke don't fix it. They don't like it, they can watch another person. My only request, not a complaint, is can you show us your ab routine and talk about sets and reps? Thank you again. You're genuine, not another telling us they discovered some new way of exercising. Simple, enjoyable, more time for other things, I look forward to the next workout instead of being tired and dreading it. Thanks again man!
comments.author: @domjohndemarco

comments.text: I found Mike Mentzer when I was around 20 years of age. The Heavy Duty training program he had at the time was brutal. Very few people could stick to it, not because of the physical aspect, but the mental aspect. The first time you train, the feeling coming out of the gym is great, but the next time you go in, it's "Oh, crap, I gotta do this again?" I found that Lee Labrada's training worked best for me -- 3 exercises, 2 sets each, 6-8 reps, 1 minute rest between sets. For back he trained 3 sets per exercise. 2 day split/4 days per week. I found it to be a hybrid between Mike Mentzer and Steve Reeves with the intensity to match.
comments.author: @firebird7479

comments.text: I'm  63 I've been training a long time, and I absolutely love your content. Since watching your channel, i started doing a three day split. The only difference is I put my leg day in the middle. I'm a big Dorian Yates fan, so I like this three day split approach. I also think you're spot on by saying if someone is just staring to do more sets to train the movement.  I like there no drama on your channel, just practical fitness advice. Thanks for sharing â¤
comments.author: @samwright738

comments.text:
Pull Day
Warm up
5m on treadmill
Band circuit. Lat raises, overhand press, curls, face pulls (2-3 sets)

Routine 2-3m rest even for warmups, 8-12 reps then progressive overload
Wide Grip Pulldown (2-3 ramping sets), 1 to Failure
Chest Supported Row 1 warmup, 1 to Failure
Reverse Pec Deck 1 warmup, 1 to Failure 
Cable Reverse Fly 1 w, 1 to failure
One Arm Cable Curls or Curls on incline 1 w, 1 to Failure

comments.text:
You are one of the very few Fitness Youtubers not treating your audience like either complete iditots or aspiring pro bodybuilders. I think most of us (your audience) are neither of that. I, for example, just like to work out and/or get fit, look strong and be healthy. 

I don't want to be occupied with fitness 24/7 with the goal of looking like a Sci/Fi mutant from outer space, lol. And i couldn't care less if my workout plan isn't as optimal according to the newest released study. I also don't care to turn my life upside down and be totally fatigued, just to squeeze out 1.5% more gains.

I am not genetic gifted with superior recovery or athleticism in general, other than some youtubers who claim that fatigue management is just lazyness ðŸ˜’. 
I need to be very careful with how much volume/Intensity i can put on my body. This is not coming from someone working out for a couple of months on and off. I train since 1994 and i realized over the years that (especially when you get older) the worst/stupid thing you can do (related to workouts at least) is to overtax your body. Because training without being fresh and accumulating more and more exhaustion (because you think you HAVE to soldier through this) doesn't get you anywhere. Eventually you HAVE to take  two or more weeks off, just to feel like a human again.

In the beginning i was trying to do super high volume workouts 6 times a week. And when my body became to tired (long before i made any progress) i didn't stop and gave my body the needed rest. No, i switched to another programm and the circle started again. Which was pretty stupid. But when everyone you read (there was no Youtube back then, only the magazines with articles about Workouts)  says you HAVE to do more and more and even more and then train harder and even harder next time, you never stop to learn to listen to your body. 
Heck, in the first 15 years, i had unlearned how it feels the train fresh and not tired. 

As you say all the time, Bodybuilding as a long-term undertaking. We as humans are so wired to think short term that it is hard to do something when the result is years in the future.  still need to restrain myself once in a whille when i work out so i don't go full out, balls to the wall and destroy myself in a workout.
I learned that the goal is NOT to train as hard as you can, but to train hard ENOUGH.
In my experience, right dosage of intensity, volume and rest time is the key. Not too much and not to little, do the RIGHT amount. The thing is most people who train to get strong/big do way too much. They often try to do workouts which where made by steroid users.

This is why i have unsubbed most of the Fitness Youtube channels i had for years, because i realized they either make videos for absolute beginners (train HARDER!!) or people who aim to be pro bodyybuilders (everything HAS to optimal on point.ALWAYS!!). 

I don't want to life like that and to be hones this is not fun anymore. 
I LOVE to train, it feels awesome and this is the only place where i feel peace and like a human (sounds funny, i know).
I train for 35 years and i would love to continue doing this for the next 35 years and more, if i am allowed to.

Sorry for the rant, i don't know why i wrote that much. Sorry for that.
comments.author: @nealsterling8151

comments.text: Babe, wake up. Eric uploaded a new video
comments.author: @fahiim_x

comments.text:
Key component here is be blessed with high test and lift in your 20s hard.  Try starting this same shit when you're 45 and you'll have a different experience. 

Lift hard, whether you go light or heavy, lift often and HARD, and do as much compound lifting as possible.  Bodybuilder lifting only gets results when you're juiced (frankly doing anything gets results when you're on gear), otherwise your stability muscle deficiencies will lead to injuries keeping you off the platforms.   The sixpack is made in the kitchen, not at the gym.  Anything else is absolute bullshit trying to sell you something.
comments.author: @Bushmills21

comments.text: Personally, I think it doesn't matter if you change your days etc. You're split. What's important is increasing the reps or the weight on any given exercise as long as you're doing that for your whole body. Your gold.
comments.author: @Explorshon123

comments.text: Bro as long as you are hitting some hard sets every week, it doesnâ€™t matter how often you change your training program. Stimulus is stimulus.
comments.author: @brandonyounzz

comments.text:
Any idea on how to track certain "slow lifts" like lateral raises? I've been doing 17.5 kg for 12-15 reps for the last 2 months. I can do 20 reps but honestly im not convinced the form is similiar enough to the point where I can count it as valid progressive overload, unlike more "heavy" exercises like shoulder press, rows etc(basically the compounds)
Like how do u expect to progress on such a excericse where you've already reached a good weight I suppose, just expect to do the same weight?
comments.author: @JayzLegendz

comments.text:
Eric, regarding percentages, how much do you think the gains decrease if you compare frequency 1 with frequency 2? Because I'm going to start a PLP routine with only 6 sets per muscle group, and I don't know how much I'd be wasting my potential.

I heard that the minimum number of sets is 10, and if you do it twice a week it's even better. And this is a bit far from what I plan to do, which would be to train 3 days a week (it's not realistic to fit 10 sets per muscle group into one day).
comments.author: @Renekor

comments.text:
I've been in and out of gyms for 20 years. Much more out. The results I've gotten could be achieved by anyone by being consistent for less than 2 years I reckon. 

So much wasted time.

comments.text: To be fair, you can only go so far in your training. I've been training since I was 14 (1978). If we had no physical or genetic limitations, I should be benching 3,000 lbs. and squatting 4,000 lbs. with 30 inch (0.76 m) arms and a lat spread wider than a condor. But, it doesn't happen that way. At some point the gains will stop and you will be in maintenance mode. That's just the way it is.

comments.text: I went from 6 days a week to training once a year. The results are amazing.
comments.author: @WilliamHudson-ug7wz

comments.text:
It works. Iâ€™ve been doing Mentzers ideal routine for some months now. Growth and strength has exploded. If youâ€™re unsure, just try it. My life quality is so much better. Didnâ€™t realize how fatigued I felt most of the time because I trained so much.

Now I have free time outside of the gym, and the energy to enjoy it.
comments.author: @commanderkeen2078

comments.text: After 10 years with periods of working out 7 days a week at 20 sets, you've reached close to your physical maximum naturally and built a solid foundation.. what is your progression like these days? Because maintaining only takes one set to failure per week. "Do what got me here not what I'm doing now, it's literally just an experiment" so this advice is for advanced lifters?
comments.author: @r34ct4

comments.text: I did the whole volume thing and barely look like I lifted, after a few years. Last year January I started training to failure, one set with additional dropsets, push pull legs. Each workout repeated within 7 days after the last workout. So if I did a push day, I'd have the next push day within 7 days. That's high intensity, little volume. I gained strength and lean mass while on a cut. Shows how bad my workouts must have been before
comments.author: @tonypaella

comments.text: Hi there, I really enjoy your content. Cutting back my training sessions from 6-7 days to 3-4 has been a gamer changer. I used to deal with really bad joint pain and inflammation in addition to not making much progress with my lifts. Initially, its hard because more is always thought to be better but honestly less is really more in this case. You'll never realize what overtraining is until you take a step back and actually heal properly and rest properly.
comments.author: @cole6383

comments.text:
Question in a built in contradiction here:
You want less sets, just pushed to max intensity/failure, but you then mention to only progress weight when all 3 sets hit the target rep (say 10 reps). But waiting until you hit 10 reps for all sets inherently means the first two sets were not intense enough or to failure?? I donâ€™t get it.
comments.author: @SpaceKraft24

comments.text: If anyone is familiar with Mindpump podcasts and channel, it wasn't until I found them about 4yrs ago that I finally got Amazing results after YEARS of overtraining and not knowing it. Most of their programs are 3 days a week when I was doing 5 to 6 with a very active job. And I never really made progress until I went to 3 days
comments.author: @backintogear9071

comments.text: Question. Someone probably already asked. But if you so strongly believe that 1 set is enough. Why do you then do incline DB press(*chest+triceps*) chest flyes(*chest*) and tricep extensions(*triceps*) you still train the muscle twice. hell the triceps is also trained with shoulder presses! So is it 1 set? 2 sets? or 3 sets? Dont mean to be a dick, but it just contradicts what you say. Love to understand what you mean. Thanks!
comments.author: @KillmWillemTube

comments.text:
''Once you stimulate a muscle with complete failure, why would you want to stimulate it more''

Does this mean you don't need more than one set per exercise/muscle per session provided you go to failure with it?

EDIT: never mind, the answer (probably, but not proven) is in the rest of the video
comments.author: @BcroG11

comments.text:
For decades my training was: MON: Chest/Shoulders/Triceps; WED: Back/Biceps; FRI: Legs/Abs. 9 sets per body part except arms -- 6 sets each for biceps and triceps (my  best bodypart, no need to train them more than I do). Now I do a 4 day split, same set up, rotating days as I train at 2 different gyms, one of which is only Saturday evenings.

I bike ride 4X week for 40 minutes. I'm 61 and have been training since I was 14. My training philosophy falls in line with Mike Mentzer, Steve Reeves and Lee Labrada.
comments.author: @firebird7479

comments.text: You don't even have to go to absolute failure.  Leave 1 rep in the tank and complete that final rep.  Progression is most important over time.  If you go from 185 on Bench for 8 reps and a few years later get 225 for 8.  You will look bigger if you eat in a surplus
comments.author: @petercalicchio4973

comments.text:
I understand giving advice about getting jacked but youâ€™re using evidence based off the present - i.e youâ€™re already jacked and are maintaining. 

If someone is just starting off, theyâ€™re a noob or a beginner, do you think following your current advice would work? For me, it seems the information and advice of the split and diets that got you from beginner to advanced would be more beneficial to beginners.
comments.author: @Elbow1878

comments.text: Isn't there a biais to say less training is more efficient when you already trained during years and years before? I agree with the part saying you don't need 2h session but if you can do PPL twice a week wouldn't you have better result than just once?
comments.author: @vivalabello

comments.text:
I'm currently taking a break from lifting and focusing on rehabbing my body with restorative training. It's definitely minimalist in nature, but I feel surprisingly good. ðŸ’¯ 

1) 3x per week : 4 sets each of strict feet elevated pushups, walking lunges for distance, and strict pullups. 

2) 3x per week : 15% max incline walking for 30 min, not holding onto the treadmill. 

3) Dog walking outdoors for 10-15K steps daily of general activity.
comments.author: @ryandeffley7652

comments.text:
Love the Mike Mentzer reference. Though, I think we have studies now that clarify the relationship between volume and growth.
I agree that alot of people don't approach their training with any type of intensity, but personally, I still recommend 2 sets minimum per exercise- the extra set is for added volume- which can lead to growth. 
Still, love the video
comments.author: @Raey_Thoven

comments.text: What is your opinion on a PPL vs UppLowUpp split if you workout on the same exact 3 days a week? (in my case monday, wednesday, friday). With a normal PPL split there's 7 days between each muscle group, but with UppLowUpp there will be 3-5 days between each muscle group. Except for legs, but I also go for runs 1-2 times a week so I don't wanna go too crazy on the legs.
comments.author: @helpfulonline

comments.text: I can't feel flys in my chest... they just hurt my shoulders
comments.author: @dillonkeller4477

comments.text: 41 and i do 2 sets to failure 4x a week targetting each muscle group twice with different exercises and I've never been happier with the results and working out does not feel like a chore anymore
comments.author: @Noid1220

comments.text: Interesting video. I recently started thinking about changing my schedule a bit. I currently do 3 workouts per week at the gym, and I can't add more. At the moment I do upper, lower, upper, but I want to try push, legs pull.
comments.author: @simonchris5426

comments.text: Thanks for this, changing my traning program starting next week. Gonna lower sets per muszle group. Was thinking about it long time ago, using Bukgarian Split Squats as example. My legs are fried after roughly 3 sets per leg, so why would be any diffrent for other muscles
comments.author: @Big_Daddy953

comments.text:
I am doing full body 3x a week, around 6 sets per muscle besides hamstring and chest which I only do 4 set a week. Feeling fresh every workout. Feels like you get much more out of every workout.

I am doing full body because I like the higher frequency better.
comments.author: @mattricav

comments.text: If i go to the gym 2x a week will this still work pushing to failure 1 to 3 reps?
comments.author: @calebwalker7619

comments.text:
Hi from uk great vlog 
I also use a three day split but run it as PLP to keep the two upper further apart to help recovery  all  one top set to failure  works well for me
comments.author: @Leonard-kd7uj

comments.text: I've been dabbling with full body routines. Do you have any insight into those? I've been doing mostly 5 day higher frequency full body but everywhere I'm reading if you're over 40 I should be doing 2-3 full body instead.
comments.author: @bastinelli443

comments.text: Could you tell us how many sets you do every bodypart every week? Thanks!
comments.author: @XplicitEnergy

comments.text:
I have been doing plp with 3 sets per exercise, 3 days a week
And now my body have more definition than when i do the oldschool (20set/week)
And recovery feels better :D
comments.author: @marshalandreas3947

comments.text: It helps my anxiety to do 4-5x week. Depending on gym programming. I go hard on the first 3 splits and deload by half on the other days or do boxing cardio.
comments.author: @kanshou

comments.text: Bro this is a breath of fresh air! Everyone's trying to eek out 1% as if they are living in a lab. I get it, you put so much time and effort in, why not optimise, But like you said, unless you are trying to get on stage, lifting hard and eating well will get you most of the way.
comments.author: @randallbroughton8011

comments.text: did u build ur physique on this or on a high volume program?
comments.author: @jonrod7990

comments.text: Would you say that this type of training is suited more for experienced lifters over newbies or is it optimal for all levels?
comments.author: @stipeskugor5020

comments.text: So if 1 series per part is enough why you are doing 2 excercises for chest? Its 2 series in the end :D
comments.author: @mditrich

comments.text: I go all out on my sets and i have tried the 1 set system and no matter what two-three sets produces better results for me.
comments.author: @whydoyouneedmyname6508

comments.text: Contually progressing forever is impossible. At some point in your life you will begin to regress. That age will be different for everyone. Train hard and listen to your body. Diet and rest are key.
comments.author: @ebowalker571

comments.text:
I'm on the A2J program for commercial gyms - I defo recommend picking it up. Eric doesn't specifically include neck work or much direct forearm work in it, but I can understand why, people are super limited on time for the core programme.  Its sometimes tough to fit them in timewise, but I want to work on it.  For forearms, I've added reverse curls with the bar before squatting. I no longer get wrist pain from squatting now - I guess it helps warm them up beforehand. Also doing some deadhangs and getting a bit from deadlifting too. Few years ago I injured my shoulder and my neck defo took a hit due to deferred pain, have been rehabing for a long time. I chose to add one neck exercise to each session e.g. neck curls, neck extensions and rotations with a band. Amazing how weak my neck curls are, I can only do around 3 sets of 25 - not even adding weight to it yet! Interesting that Eric is doing a much lower rep range, maybe I'll work toward that.

Also surprising to hear Mentzer didn't think direct work was so necessary - I can't see how the neck itself, as opposed to your traps, would get hit much by compounds? Forearms sure, people often make that case, but still think its helpful.
comments.author: @benevans801

comments.text:
After following your advice for a month now and after having been spinning my wheels for two years with little or no gains to speak of, I just hit a PR today on flat dumbbell bench and am ready to progress next week. I'm finally starting to see the beginnings of  a difference in my physique. Thank you for setting it straight for me and cutting through the noise.
High intensity, simplicity, challenging lifts and failure.
Your recipe is one that is finally working for me.
I salute you sir.
comments.author: @Lamhfhad

comments.text: The weighted neck curl and reverse neck curl were staples of my training as a teenager in my basement and early days in the gym. But a herniated disc between C6-C7 prevents me from doing them. The neck muscles are critical especially now with all the forward head posture from cellphone use. The forearms are a different story. I've done wrist curls, had a homemade wrist roller I concocted as a teen. Built tremendous grip strength but the forearms just didn't grow. I'm genetically predisposed to small forearms.
comments.author: @firebird7479

Starting incline bench and military press was a real game changer for me. Flat bench never really developed my shoulders and upper chest.

Forearms were always naturally big, and my neck was slightly thicker than average hehe
comments.author: @MCWellnessCoach

comments.text: Your physique looks like young dorian's physique!
comments.author: @ImmanuelD733

comments.text: Man I love neck training, my neck grew 3cm in only 3 weeks of doing 2 sets twice a week
comments.author: @Lorio_

comments.text: Bro, any tips to get the mind muscle connection while doing lat pulldown?

comments.text: Good stuff. I just started forearm training too and put it into my shoulder / traps day

comments.text: So serious question with your style of training. You talk about the numbers going up and chasing prs and constantly looking at improving the weight but are your muscles growing ?? Most guys who want to get in shape and get a better body arenâ€™t trying to improve numbers there trying to improve what they see in the mirror. You have shown pics before and other people have commented on the fact you donâ€™t look any bigger. So is your physique staying the same due to muscle memory and some stimulus itâ€™s getting but your numbers are going up ?? That sounds more like strength based training rather than hypertrophy. This isnâ€™t an insult or taking shots at you am genuinely just baffled with how much conflicting advice there seems to be. A lot of people are promoting low volume training now a days but the thing is nobody who is promoting it built there body doing that style of training so what is the answer. I couldnâ€™t really care about the numbers I want to look in the mirror and feel happy with what I see and have a muscular physique
comments.author: @jamesgoodwin5360

comments.text: would love to see a full workout video to see how you train especially to failure and how it should look like
comments.author: @syntrixlive7466

comments.text: Do you experience joint pain when going heavy? because i have tried both styles of training and when going heavy with few sets my joints just seem to take a beating and limit my training, so is it still possible to get the same results with higher reps and a little lower weight?
comments.author: @niklasrelund4223

comments.text: Damn I love your videos. Today is Saturday. I don't workout on weekends but after this video, I'm so motivated, but I'll fight the urge. The other motivational videos from other people are exhausting and confusing just from watching them. Thank you for another no bs, straight forward and simple video
comments.author: @domjohndemarco

comments.text: I'm 61 and have been training since the age of 14. There will a point in time where will you look the same. There's only so far you can go physically in size and in strength. At some point in your life, the injuries will catch up with you, and you will end up training lighter.
comments.author: @firebird7479

comments.text: I wonder if you had any advice for people (like me) with diastasis recti (separation of the abs / linen middle).  I would like to have more abs but looks like doing the regular crunches are not indicated.  I do understand some body builders have this condition precisely due to the exercising, I wonder what exercises they can do for their abs.
comments.author: @Raist3db

comments.text: Good video man.â€¦ I believe in this Mike Menzer-type training just started a tictoc channel  â€¦ about  all this stuff plus my journey to getting fit again at age 45. I need help lol
comments.author: @paulmaguire3155

comments.text: You can tell this guy is a natty and I respect the hell out of that.
comments.author: @UmbraChenoweth

comments.text: If I can only work out 3 days per week would you recommend alternating upper and lower every other workout or would a push, leg pull split be better?
comments.author: @robarsenault8415

comments.text: what is your weight and height?
comments.author: @ThinhTran-nk7uk

comments.text: what do you think of squeezing the muscle at the top each rep? I only feel a muscle if i do that

comments.text: This whole video was me to a T. About 4 months ago I decided to focus on big compound lifts and stick to them no matter how much my brain tells me to switch things up. I also stopped listening to 90% of the content I was previously. Yes, a few gains physically, but the mental feels so much better and is the real win. Appreciate your words.
